key_points: Covid-19 has become the deadliest disease event in American history, surpassing the death toll of the 1918 Spanish flu.
The 1918 Spanish flu caused approximately 675,000 American deaths, whereas Covid-19 deaths in the U.S. have exceeded 675,400.
The U.S. represents about 14% of global Covid-19 deaths, with a national population that is only 4.2% of the global total.
Experts compare Covid-19's impact to historical events like the Civil War, questioning if it's the deadliest event in U.S. history.
The U.S. response to Covid-19 has been criticized, especially regarding its early stages.
Comparisons between Covid-19 and the Spanish flu must consider differences in population size, age of fatalities, and available medical technology.
Vaccines have significantly reduced the risk of death from Covid-19, yet fatalities continue.
The global Covid-19 death toll is likely an underestimate, with research suggesting U.S. deaths could be 10% higher than reported.
The pandemic has prompted a reevaluation of historical precedents for responding to disease outbreaks.
Historians and medical professionals emphasize the importance of learning from the current pandemic for future preparedness.
spokespersons: Howard Markel (Director, Center for the History of Medicine, University of Michigan School of Public Health)
David Morens (Medical Historian, National Institutes of Allergy and Infectious Diseases)
